Replying to @liamdaws 2018-06-12 01:29
@liamdaws @toddmorey @k2heikkila @bphogan @NetlifyCMS @Netlify @NetlifyCMS is free and open source and does not depend on @Netlify. It needs a git API like that offered by GitHub, but you can deploy the output to anything you like.

Replying to @richhiggins 2018-06-11 22:06
@richhiggins @JamesMcCormack @Netlify Thanks Rich! There certainly is a lot of choice. That's one of the reasons I favor #JAMstack sites. You have a lot of portability and can avoid lock-in. Always nice to use a service because it is then best for you rather than because it is hard to leave!

Replying to @ 2018-06-11 20:01
@k2heikkila @bphogan @NetlifyCMS @Netlify Yeah this is exactly what @NetlifyCMS was intended to enable. - Use any static site generator - Author in markdown if you like - Give a nice authoring experience, invisibly using git behind the scenes - Developers work how they want. Authors work how they want. - CI/CD
